title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases under title 38, United States Code. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" repeals the minimum internment period for presumption of service connection for diseases under title 38, United States Code. It also adds heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis to the list of diseases presumed to be service-connected. Additionally, it grants administrative authority for determining service connection for these additional diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends title 38, United States Code to include diseases associated with being a prisoner of war for presumption of service connection. The Secretary can determine diseases warranting this presumption based on medical evidence. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends title 38, United States Code to include diseases associated with being a prisoner of war for presumption of service connection. The Secretary considers recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War and other medical information in determining diseases warranting this presumption. The association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is deemed positive if credible evidence supports it. The Secretary must determine if a presumption of service connection is warranted for a disease recommended by the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. If warranted, proposed regulations must be issued within 60 days. If not warranted, a notice must be published in the Federal Register within the same timeframe. The Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register within 60 days if a presumption of service connection for a disease is not warranted. Final regulations must be issued within 90 days after proposed regulations are published. If a disease is removed from regulations, veterans awarded compensation for that disease may be affected. Whenever a disease is removed from regulations, veterans and survivors entitled to compensation will continue to receive benefits. The Secretary must consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War when carrying out this process. The Secretary must consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War when making changes to regulations regarding diseases for veterans and survivors entitled to compensation. Amendments to section 1112(b) of the title include specifying diseases under subsection (d).
